repo.name: neovim

body: I have found myself needing this and implementing it via a filter somewhat regularly, so figured I'd make a PR.

comment_data.body:
wouldn't this be really inefficient if you take just a few elements from a huge iterator?
Not really familiar with the iterators so can't tell if there is a better way
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -592,6 +592,27 @@ function ListIter.rfind(self, f) -- luacheck: no unused args
   self._head = self._tail
 end
 
+--- Consumes an iterator, yielding only the first n values.
+---
+--- Example:
+---
+--- ```lua
+--- local it = vim.iter({ 1, 2, 3, 4 }):take(2)
+--- it:next()
+--- -- 1
+--- it:next()
+--- -- 2
+--- it:next()
+--- -- nil
+--- ```
+function Iter.take(self, n)
+  local i = 0
+  return self:filter(function()
+    i = i + 1
+    return i <= n

comment_data.body: Yeah, you're right. I think the use case would mostly be with smaller iterators or places where a limit is needed, but maybe it could be made to not consume the entire iterator?
comment_data.diff_hunk:

comment_data.body: Couldn't the same argument be made for `skip` / `nth`, etc. though?

comment_data.body: well I don't know how they are implemented but if they are the same way (using `filter`) then yes

comment_data.body: I think it could be made better for ListIters, let me see if I can get something working that doesn't consume the entire iterator.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -592,6 +592,27 @@ function ListIter.rfind(self, f) -- luacheck: no unused args
   self._head = self._tail
 end
 
+--- Consumes an iterator, yielding only the first n values.

comment_data.body:
and `nth` is implemented with `skip`, and skip is just 

```lua
for _ = 1, n do
  local _ = self:next()
end
return self
```

I think `take` is tough to make not consume the iterator because it needs to return the iterator, not a list of results... unless it collects n results and then creates a new iterator, which is even less efficient.

Edit: it can be made to not consume the full iterator if the result of `take` is not `self` and we instead create a new iterator with a function, like `return Iter.new(function() if i < n then return self:next() end)`, but I'm not sure if that's better or worse.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -592,6 +592,27 @@ function ListIter.rfind(self, f) -- luacheck: no unused args
   self._head = self._tail
 end
 
+--- Consumes an iterator, yielding only the first n values.

+--- it:next()

@@ -592,6 +592,37 @@ function ListIter.rfind(self, f) -- luacheck: no unused args
   self._head = self._tail
 end
 
+--- Consumes an iterator, yielding only the first n values.
+---
+--- Example:
+---
+--- ```lua
+--- local it = vim.iter({ 1, 2, 3, 4 }):take(2)
+--- it:next()
+--- -- 1
+--- it:next()
+--- -- 2
+--- it:next()
+--- -- nil
+--- ```
+function Iter.take(self, n)
+  local next = self.next
+  local i = 0
+  self.next = function()
+    if i < n then
+      i = i + 1
+      return next(self)
+    end
+  end
+  return self
+end
+
+function ListIter.take(self, n)

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
--- Transforms an iterator to yield only the first n values.
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -592,6 +592,37 @@ function ListIter.rfind(self, f) -- luacheck: no unused args
   self._head = self._tail
 end
 
+--- Consumes an iterator, yielding only the first n values.

comment_regular_data.body: I can ignore the news.txt failure right? Seems unnecessary to add this to news since `iter` is still new to 0.10.

This can (and should) have a `ListIter` specialization that simply moves `_tail`. This will be very fast for arrays.

For regular iterators, I don't think `filter` is the right approach. Try something like this (not tested):

```lua
function Iter.take(self, n)
  local next = self.next
  local i = 0
  self.next = function()
    if i <= n then
      i = i + 1
      return next()
    end
  end
end
```

> This can (and should) have a `ListIter` specialization that simply moves `_tail`. This will be very fast for arrays.

You're totally right, implementing that now. 

> For regular iterators, I don't think `filter` is the right approach. Try something like this (not tested):
> ...

Wow that's so much better... I should've thought this one through more, my bad. Thanks for the reviews! I'll have a new version pushed shortly.

Great talk at NeovimConf btw, enjoyed it a lot :)
Thanks! First thing I've had merged, pretty exciting :)

title: feat(iter): add `Iter.take`
